Variational Language Concepts for Interpreting
Foundation Language Models

Hengyi Wang    Shiwei Tan    Zhqing Hong    Desheng Zhang    Hao Wang

Department of Computer Science, Rutgers University Correspondence to: Hengyi Wang <hengyi.wang@rutgers.edu>
Abstract

Foundation Language Models (FLMs) such as BERT and its variants have achieved remarkable success in natural language processing. To date, the interpretability of FLMs has primarily relied on the attention weights in their self-attention layers. However, these attention weights only provide word-level interpretations, failing to capture higher-level structures, and are therefore lacking in readability and intuitiveness. To address this challenge, we first provide a formal definition of conceptual interpretation and then propose a variational Bayesian framework, dubbed VAriational Language Concept (VALC), to go beyond word-level interpretations and provide concept-level interpretations. Our theoretical analysis shows that our VALC finds the optimal language concepts to interpret FLM predictions. Empirical results on several real-world datasets show that our method can successfully provide conceptual interpretation for FLMs111Code will soon be available at https://github.com/Wang-ML-Lab/interpretable-foundation-models.

Variational Language Concepts for Interpreting
Foundation Language Models


Hengyi Wang††thanks: Correspondence to: Hengyi Wang <hengyi.wang@rutgers.edu>    Shiwei Tan    Zhqing Hong    Desheng Zhang    Hao Wang Department of Computer Science, Rutgers University


1 Introduction

Foundation language models (FLMs) such as BERT (Devlin et al., 2018) and its variants (Lan et al., 2019; Liu et al., 2019; He et al., 2021; Portes et al., 2023) have achieved remarkable success in natural language processing. These FLMs are usually large attention-based neural networks that follow a pretrain-finetune paradigm, where models are first pretrained on large datasets and then finetuned for a specific task. As with any machine learning models, interpretability in FLMs has always been a desideratum, especially in decision-critical applications (e.g., healthcare).

To date, FLMs’ interpretability has primarily relied on the attention weights in self-attention layers. However, these attention weights only provide raw word-level importance scores as interpretations. Such low-level interpretations fail to capture higher-level semantic structures, and hence lack readability and intuitiveness. For example, low-level interpretations often fail to capture influence of similar words to predictions, leading to unstable or even unreasonable explanations (see Sec. 5.4 for details).

In this paper, we aim to go beyond word-level attention and interpret FLM predictions at the concept level. Such higher-level semantic interpretations are complementary to word-level importance scores and often more readable and intuitive. For example, as shown in Fig. 1, VALC interprets the FLM with the following multi-level concepts (details in Appendix F):

  • •

    Dataset-level concepts are highlighted by the top words and the distribution of their embeddings in the PLM (Fig. 1(left)). For example, Concept 20 (Government) corresponds to the red ellipse, encompassing words relevant to government entities and activities, as shown in Fig. 1(left).

  • •

    Document-level concepts are demonstrated by each document’s topics; for instance, in the 3 bars representing probability distribution over 3 concepts for the document in Fig. 1(middle), VALC identifies Concept 24, i.e., ‘politics’, and Concept 20, i.e., ‘government’, as considerably more relevant concepts compared to Concept 27, i.e. ‘names’.

  • •

    Word-level concepts are identified by words in documents. For example, in the box displaying the document in Fig. 1(right), VALC highlights the words ‘chided’ and ‘tax’ because they are highly related to Concept 20, i.e., ‘government’. Terms like ‘Senate’ and ‘bitty’ are associated with Concept 24, i.e. ‘politics’, aligning with the document-level concepts.

We start by developing a comprehensive and formal definition of conceptual interpretation with four desirable properties: (1) multi-level structure, (2) normalization, (3) additivity, and (4) mutual information maximization. With this definition, we then propose a variational Bayesian framework, dubbed VAriational Language Concept (VALC), to provide dataset-level, document-level, and word-level (the first property) conceptual interpretation for FLM predictions. Our theoretical analysis shows that maximizing our VALC’s evidence lower bound is equivalent to inferring the optimal conceptual interpretation with Properties (1-3) while maximizing the mutual information between the inferred concepts and the observed embeddings from FLMs, i.e., Property (4).

Drawing inspiration from hierarchical Bayesian deep learning Wang and Yeung (2016, 2020); Wang et al. (2016), the core of our idea is to treat a FLM’s contextual word embeddings (and their corresponding attention weights) as observed variables and build a probabilistic generative model to automatically infer the higher-level semantic structures (e.g., concepts or topics) from these embeddings and attention weights, thereby interpreting the FLM’s predictions at the concept level. Our VALC is compatible with any attention-based FLMs and can work as an conceptual interpreter, which explains the FLM predictions at multiple levels with theoretical guarantees. Our contributions are as follows:

  • •

    We identify the problem of multi-level interpretations for FLM predictions, develop a formal definition of conceptual interpretation, and propose VALC as the first general method to infer such conceptual interpretation.

  • •

    Theoretical analysis shows that learning VALC is equivalent to inferring the optimal conceptual interpretation according to our definition.

  • •

    Quantitative and qualitative analysis on real-world datasets show that VALC can infer meaningful language concepts to effectively and intuitively interpret FLM predictions.

2 Related Work

Foundation Language Models. Foundation language models are large attention-based neural networks that follow a pretrain-finetune paradigm. Usually they are first pretrained on large datasets in a self-supervised manner and then finetuned for a specific downstream task. BERT (Devlin et al., 2018) is a pioneering FLM that has shown impressive performance across multiple downstream tasks. Following BERT, there have been variants He et al. (2021); Clark et al. (2020); Yang et al. (2019); Liu et al. (2019); Lewis et al. (2019) that design different self-supervised learning objectives or training schemes to achieve better performance. While FLMs offer attention weights for interpreting predictions at the word level, these interpretations lack readability and intuitiveness because they fail to capture higher-level semantic structures.

Interpretation Methods for FLMs. Existing conceptual interpretation methods for FLMs typically rely on topic models Blei et al. (2003); Blei and Lafferty (2006); Blei (2012); Wang et al. (2012); Chang and Blei (2009); Mcauliffe and Blei (2007); Hoffman et al. (2010) and prototypical part networks Chen et al. (2019). There has been recent work that employs deep neural networks to learn topic models more efficiently (Card et al., 2017; Xing et al., 2017; Peinelt et al., 2020), using techniques such as amortized variational inference. There is also work that improves upon traditional topic models by either leveraging word similarity as a regularizer for topic-word distributions (Das et al., 2015; Batmanghelich et al., 2016) or including word embeddings into the generative process (Hu et al., 2012; Dieng et al., 2020; Bunk and Krestel, 2018; Duan et al., 2021). There is also work that builds topic models upon embeddings from FLMs (Grootendorst, 2020; Zhang et al., 2022; Wang et al., 2022; Zhao et al., 2020; Meng et al., 2022). However, these methods often rely on a pipeline involving dimensionality reduction and basic clustering, which is not end-to-end, leading to potential information loss between FLM embeddings and clustering outcomes. This can result in unfaithful interpretations for the underlying FLM. Additionally, they typically generate interpretations at a single level (e.g., document level), lacking a multi-level conceptual structure.

Beyond topic models, attribution-based approaches such as LIME Ribeiro et al. (2016) and SHAP Lundberg and Lee (2017) assign importance to input features to explain predictions. Concept bottleneck models (CBMs) Koh et al. (2020); Yuksekgonul et al. (2023); Yang et al. (2023); Kim et al. (2018); Schulz et al. (2020); Paranjape et al. (2020); Schrouff et al. (2021) offer interpretations by learning conceptual activation and then performing classifications on these concepts, while inherent models Xie et al. (2023); Ren et al. (2023); Shi et al. (2021) focus on model redesign/re-training for interpretability. However, these approaches often require extra supervision or re-training, making them unsuitable for our setting. In contrast, our method is inherently multi-level and end-to-end, models concepts across dataset, document, and word levels, and produces faithful post-hoc interpretations for any models based on FLMs with theoretical guarantees.

3 Methods

In this section, we formalize the definition of conceptual interpretation, and describe our proposed VALC for conceptual interpretation of FLMs.

3.1 Problem Setting and Notation

We consider a corpus of M𝑀Mitalic_M documents, where the m𝑚mitalic_m’th document contains Jmsubscript𝐽𝑚J_{m}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT words, and a FLM f⁢(𝒟m)𝑓subscript𝒟𝑚f(\mathcal{D}_{m})italic_f ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), which takes as input the document m𝑚mitalic_m (denoted as 𝒟msubscript𝒟𝑚\mathcal{D}_{m}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) with Jmsubscript𝐽𝑚J_{m}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT words and outputs (1) a CLS embedding 𝐜m∈ℝdsubscript𝐜𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑{\bf c}_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, (2) Jmsubscript𝐽𝑚J_{m}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contextual word embeddings 𝐞m≜[𝐞m⁢j]j=1Jm≜subscript𝐞𝑚superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚{\bf e}_{m}\triangleq[{\bf e}_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≜ [ bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and (3) the attention weights 𝐚m(h)≜[am⁢j(h)]j=1Jm≜superscriptsubscript𝐚𝑚ℎsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑚𝑗ℎ𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚{\bf a}_{m}^{(h)}\triangleq[a_{mj}^{(h)}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≜ [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT between each word and the last-layer CLS token, where hℎhitalic_h denotes the hℎhitalic_h’th attention head. We denote the average attention weight over H heads as am⁢j=1H⁢∑h=1Ham⁢j(h)subscript𝑎𝑚𝑗1𝐻superscriptsubscriptℎ1𝐻superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑚𝑗ℎa_{mj}=\tfrac{1}{H}\sum_{h=1}^{H}a_{mj}^{(h)}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and correspondingly 𝐚m≜[am⁢j]j=1Jm≜subscript𝐚𝑚superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑎𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚{\bf a}_{m}\triangleq[a_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≜ [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (see the FLM at the bottom of Fig. 2).

In FLMs, these last-layer CLS embeddings are used as document-level representations for downstream tasks (e.g., document classification). Furthermore, our VALC assumes K𝐾Kitalic_K concepts (topics) for the corpus. For document m𝑚mitalic_m, our VALC interpreter tries to infer a concept distribution vector 𝜽m∈ℝKsubscript𝜽𝑚superscriptℝ𝐾\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (also known as the topic proportion in topic models) for the whole document and a concept distribution vector ϕm⁢j=[ϕm⁢j⁢k]k=1K∈ℝKsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘𝑘1𝐾superscriptℝ𝐾\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}=[\phi_{mjk}]_{k=1}^{K}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for word j𝑗jitalic_j in document m𝑚mitalic_m. In our continuous embedding space, the k𝑘kitalic_k’th concept is represented by a Gaussian distribution, 𝒩⁢(𝝁k,𝚺k)𝒩subscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘\mathcal{N}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k})caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), of contextual word embeddings; we use shorthand 𝛀k=(𝝁k,𝚺k)subscript𝛀𝑘subscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$\unboldmath}_{k}=(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},% \mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})bold_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for brevity. The goal is to interpret FLMs’ predictions at the concept level using the inferred document-level concept vector 𝜽msubscript𝜽𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, word-level concept vector ϕm⁢jsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the learned embedding distributions {𝒩⁢(𝝁k,𝚺k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscript𝒩subscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{\mathcal{N}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=1}^{K}{ caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for each concept (see Sec. 5.4 for detailed descriptions and visualizations).

3.2 Formal Definition of Language Concepts

Below we formally define ‘conceptual interpretation’ for FLM predictions (see notations in Sec. 3.1):

Definition 3.1 (Conceptual Interpretation).

Assume K𝐾Kitalic_K concepts and a dataset 𝒟𝒟{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D containing M𝑀Mitalic_M documents, each with Jmsubscript𝐽𝑚J_{m}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT words (1≤m≤M1𝑚𝑀1\leq m\leq M1 ≤ italic_m ≤ italic_M). Conceptual interpretation for a document m𝑚mitalic_m consists of K𝐾Kitalic_K dataset-level variables {𝛀k}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛀𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$\unboldmath}_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}{ bold_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, a document-level variable 𝜽msubscript𝜽𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Jmsubscript𝐽𝑚J_{m}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT word-level variables {ϕm⁢j}j=1Jmsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{ bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with the following properties:

  1. (1)

    Multi-Level Structure. Conceptual interpretation has a three-level structure:

    1. (a)

      Each dataset-level variable 𝛀k=(𝝁k,𝚺k)subscript𝛀𝑘subscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$\unboldmath}_{k}=(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},% \mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})bold_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) describes the k𝑘kitalic_k’th concept; 𝝁k∈ℝdsubscript𝝁𝑘superscriptℝ𝑑\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝚺k∈ℝd×dsubscript𝚺𝑘superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d\times d}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d × italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the mean and covariance of the k𝑘kitalic_k’th concept in the embedding space (i.e., 𝐞m⁢j∈ℝdsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗superscriptℝ𝑑{\bf e}_{mj}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), respectively.

    2. (b)

      Each document-level variable 𝜽m∈ℝ≥0Ksubscript𝜽𝑚subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝐾absent0\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{K}_{\geq 0}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT describes document m𝑚mitalic_m’s relation to the K𝐾Kitalic_K concepts.

    3. (c)

      Each word-level variable ϕm⁢j∈ℝ≥0Ksubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝐾absent0\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{K}_{\geq 0}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT describes word j𝑗jitalic_j’s relation to the K𝐾Kitalic_K concepts.

  2. (2)

    Normalization. The document- and word-level interpretations, 𝜽msubscript𝜽𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ϕm⁢jsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, are normalized:

    1. (a)

      ∑k=1Kθm⁢k=1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜃𝑚𝑘1\sum_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{mk}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 for document m𝑚mitalic_m.

    2. (b)

      ∑k=1Kϕm⁢j⁢k=1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘1\sum_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{mjk}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 for word j𝑗jitalic_j in document m𝑚mitalic_m.

  3. (3)

    Additivity. We can add/subtract the k𝑘kitalic_k’s concept from the contextual embeddings 𝐞m⁢jsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗{\bf e}_{mj}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of word j𝑗jitalic_j in document m𝑚mitalic_m, i.e., 𝐞m⁢j←𝐞m⁢j±xk⁢𝝁k←subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗plus-or-minussubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝝁𝑘{\bf e}_{mj}\leftarrow{\bf e}_{mj}\pm x_{k}\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ← bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ± italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the editing weight of concept k𝑘kitalic_k).

  4. (4)

    Mutual Information Maximization. The conceptual interpretation achieves maximum mutual information between the observed embeddings 𝐞msubscript𝐞𝑚{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in FLMs and the document-level/word-level interpretation, 𝜽msubscript𝜽𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ϕm⁢jsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In Definition 3.1, Property (1) provides comprehensive three-level conceptual interpretation for FLM predictions, Property (2) ensures proper normalization in concept assignment at the document and word levels, Property (3) enables better concept editing (more details in Sec. 5.3) to modify FLM predictions, and Property (4) ensures minimal information loss when interpreting FLM predictions.

3.3 VAriational Language Concepts (VALC)

Method Overview. Drawing inspiration from hierarchical Bayesian deep learning Wang and Yeung (2016, 2020); Wang et al. (2016); Mao et al. (2022); Yan and Wang (2023); Xu et al. (2023); Wang et al. (2024), we propose our model, VAriational Language Concepts (VALC), to infer the optimal conceptual interpretation described in Definition 3.1. Different from static word embeddings (Mikolov et al., 2013) and topic models, FLMs produce contextual word embeddings with continuous-value entries [𝐞m⁢j]j=1Jmsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚[{\bf e}_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}[ bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and more importantly, associate each word embedding with a continuous-value attention weight [am⁢j]j=1Jmsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑎𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚[a_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}[ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; therefore this brings unique challenges.

To effectively discover latent concept structures learned by FLMs at the dataset level and interpret FLM predictions at the data-instance level, our VALC treats both the contextual word embeddings and their associated attention weights as observations to learn a probabilistic generative model of these observations, as shown in Fig. 2. The key idea is to use the attention weights from FLMs to compute a virtual continuous count for each word, and model the contextual word embedding distributions with Gaussian mixtures. The generative process of VALC is as follows (we mark key connection to FLMs in blue and show the corresponding graphical model in Fig. 3):

For each document m,1≤m≤M𝑚1𝑚𝑀m,1\leq m\leq Mitalic_m , 1 ≤ italic_m ≤ italic_M,

  1. 1.

    Draw the document-level concept distribution vector 𝜽m∼Dirichlet⁢(𝜶)similar-tosubscript𝜽𝑚Dirichlet𝜶\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}\sim\text{Dirichlet}(\mbox{\boldmath$% \alpha$\unboldmath})bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ Dirichlet ( bold_italic_α ).

  2. 2.

    For each word j𝑗jitalic_j (1≤j≤Jm)1𝑗subscript𝐽𝑚(1\leq j\leq J_{m})( 1 ≤ italic_j ≤ italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ),

    1. (a)

      Draw the word-level concept index zm⁢j∼Categorical⁢(𝜽m)similar-tosubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗Categoricalsubscript𝜽𝑚z_{mj}\sim\text{Categorical}(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ Categorical ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

    2. (b)

      With a continuous word count wm⁢j∈ℝsubscript𝑤𝑚𝑗ℝw_{mj}\in\mathbb{R}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R from the FLM’s attention weights, draw the contextual word embedding of the FLM from the corresponding Gaussian component 𝐞m⁢j∼𝒩⁢(𝝁zm⁢j,𝚺zm⁢j)similar-tosubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗𝒩subscript𝝁subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝚺subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗{\bf e}_{mj}\sim\mathcal{N}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{% \boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

Given the generative process above, discovery of latent concept structures in FLMs at the dataset level boils down to learning the parameters {𝝁k,𝚺k}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}% \}_{k=1}^{K}{ bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for the K𝐾Kitalic_K concepts. Intuitively the global parameters {𝝁k,𝚺k}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}% \}_{k=1}^{K}{ bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are shared across different documents, and they define a mixture of K𝐾Kitalic_K Gaussian distributions. Each Gaussian distribution describes a ‘cluster’ of words and their contextual word embeddings.

Similarly, interpretations of FLM predictions at the data-instance level is equivalent to inferring the latent variables, i.e., document-level concept distribution vectors 𝜽msubscript𝜽𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and word-level concept indices zm⁢jsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗z_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Below we highlight several important aspects of our VALC designs.

Attention Weights as Continuous Word Counts. Different from typical topic models (Blei et al., 2003; Blei, 2012) and word embeddings (Mikolov et al., 2013) that can only handle discrete word counts, our VALC can handle continuous (virtual) word counts; this better aligns with continuous attention weights in FLMs. Specifically, we denote as wm⁢j∈ℝ≥0subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗subscriptℝabsent0w_{mj}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{\geq 0}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the (non-negative real-valued) continuous word count for the j𝑗jitalic_j’th word in document m𝑚mitalic_m. We explore three schemes of computing wm⁢jsubscript𝑤𝑚𝑗w_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

  • •

    Identical Weights: Use identical weights for different words, i.e., wm⁢j=1,∀m,jsubscript𝑤𝑚𝑗1for-all𝑚𝑗w_{mj}=1,\forall m,jitalic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 , ∀ italic_m , italic_j. This is equivalent to typical discrete word counts.

  • •

    Attention-Based Weights with Fixed Length: Use wm⁢j=J′⁢am⁢jsubscript𝑤𝑚𝑗superscript𝐽′subscript𝑎𝑚𝑗w_{mj}=J^{\prime}a_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where J′superscript𝐽′J^{\prime}italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a fixed sequence length shared across all documents.

  • •

    Attention-Based Weights with Variable Length: Use wm⁢j=Jm⁢am⁢j/∑i=1Jmam⁢isubscript𝑤𝑚𝑗subscript𝐽𝑚subscript𝑎𝑚𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝐽𝑚subscript𝑎𝑚𝑖w_{mj}=\nicefrac{{J_{m}a_{mj}}}{{\sum_{i=1}^{J_{m}}a_{mi}}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = / start_ARG italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, where Jmsubscript𝐽𝑚J_{m}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is true sequence length without padding. Note that in practice, ∑i=1Jmam⁢i≠1superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝐽𝑚subscript𝑎𝑚𝑖1\sum_{i=1}^{J_{m}}a_{mi}\neq 1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ 1 due to padding tokens in FLMs.

Contextual Continuous Word Representations. Note that different from topic models (Blei et al., 2003) and typical word embeddings (Mikolov et al., 2013; Dieng et al., 2020) where word representations are static, word representations in FLMs are contextual; specifically, the same word can have different embeddings in different documents (contexts). For example, the word ‘soft’ can appear as the j1subscript𝑗1j_{1}italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’th word in document m1subscript𝑚1m_{1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and as the j2subscript𝑗2j_{2}italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’th word in document m2subscript𝑚2m_{2}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and therefore have two different embeddings (i.e., 𝐞m1⁢j1≠𝐞m2⁢j2subscript𝐞subscript𝑚1subscript𝑗1subscript𝐞subscript𝑚2subscript𝑗2{\bf e}_{m_{1}j_{1}}\neq{\bf e}_{m_{2}j_{2}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).

Correspondingly, in our VALC, we do not constrain the same word to have a static embedding; instead we assume that a word embedding is drawn from a Gaussian distribution corresponding to its latent topic. Note that word representations in our VALC is continuous, which is different from typical topic models (Blei et al., 2003) based on (discrete) bag-of-words representations.

3.4 Objective Function

Below we discuss the inference and learning procedure for VALC. We start by introducing the inference of document-level and word-level concepts (i.e., zm⁢jsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗z_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝜽msubscript𝜽𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) given the global concept parameters (i.e., {(𝝁k,𝚺k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), and then introduce the learning of these global concept parameters.

3.4.1 Inference

Inferring Document-Level and Word-Level Concepts. We formulate the problem of interpreting FLM predictions at the concept level as inferring document-level and word-level concepts. Specifically, given global concept parameters {(𝝁k,𝚺k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the contextual word embeddings 𝐞m≜[𝐞m⁢j]j=1Jm≜subscript𝐞𝑚superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚{\bf e}_{m}\triangleq[{\bf e}_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≜ [ bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the associated attention weights 𝐚m≜[am⁢j]j=1Jm≜subscript𝐚𝑚superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑎𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚{\bf a}_{m}\triangleq[a_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≜ [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, a FLM produces for each document m𝑚mitalic_m, our VALC infers the posterior distribution of the document-level concept vector 𝜽msubscript𝜽𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., p⁢(𝜽m|𝐞m,𝐚m,{(𝝁k,𝚺k)}k=1K)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝜽𝑚subscript𝐞𝑚subscript𝐚𝑚superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|{\bf e}_{m},{\bf a}_{m},\{(\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=1% }^{K})italic_p ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), and the posterior distribution of the word-level concept index zm⁢jsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗z_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., p⁢(zm⁢j|𝐞m,𝐚m,{(𝝁k,𝚺k)}k=1K)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝐞𝑚subscript𝐚𝑚superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾p(z_{mj}|{\bf e}_{m},{\bf a}_{m},\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox% {\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=1}^{K})italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Variational Distributions. These posterior distributions are intractable; we therefore resort to variational inference (Jordan et al., 1998; Blei et al., 2003) and use variational distributions q⁢(𝜽m|𝜸m)𝑞conditionalsubscript𝜽𝑚subscript𝜸𝑚q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {m})italic_q ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and q⁢(zm⁢j|ϕm⁢j)𝑞conditionalsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗q(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to approximate them. Here 𝜸m∈ℝKsubscript𝜸𝑚superscriptℝ𝐾\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{K}bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ϕm⁢j≜[ϕm⁢j⁢k]k=1K∈ℝK≜subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘𝑘1𝐾superscriptℝ𝐾\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\triangleq[\phi_{mjk}]_{k=1}^{K}\in{% \mathbb{R}}^{K}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≜ [ italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are variational parameters to be estimated during inference. This leads to the following joint variational distribution:

q⁢(𝜽m,{𝐳m⁢j}j=1Jm|𝜸m,{ϕm⁢j}j=1Jm)𝑞subscript𝜽𝑚conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐳𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚subscript𝜸𝑚superscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚\displaystyle q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m},\{{\bf z}_{mj}\}_{j=1}% ^{J_{m}}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$% \unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}})italic_q ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
=\displaystyle=~{}= q⁢(𝜽m|𝜸m)⋅∏j=1Jmq⁢(zm⁢j|ϕm⁢j).⋅𝑞conditionalsubscript𝜽𝑚subscript𝜸𝑚superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚𝑞conditionalsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗\displaystyle q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma% $\unboldmath}_{m})\cdot\prod\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}q(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$% \phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}).italic_q ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⋅ ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (1)

Evidence Lower Bound. For each document m𝑚mitalic_m, finding the optimal variational distributions is then equivalent to maximizing the following evidence lower bound (ELBO):

ℒ⁢(𝜸m,{ϕm⁢j}j=1Jm;𝜶,{(𝝁k,𝚺k)}k=1K)ℒsubscript𝜸𝑚superscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚𝜶superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾\displaystyle\mathcal{L}(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{% \boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}};\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$% \unboldmath},\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=1}^{K})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; bold_italic_α , { ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
=\displaystyle=~{}= 𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝜽m|𝜶)]+∑j=1Jm𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(zm⁢j|𝜽m)]subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝜽𝑚𝜶superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝜽𝑚\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|% \mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath})]+\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{\mathbb{E}}_% {q}[\log p(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_α ) ] + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
+∑j=1Jm𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝐞m⁢j|zm⁢j,𝝁zm⁢j,𝚺zm⁢j)]superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝚺subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗\displaystyle+\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|% z_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})]+ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
−𝔼q⁢[log⁡q⁢(𝜽m)]−∑j=1Jm𝔼q⁢[log⁡q⁢(zm⁢j)],subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑞subscript𝜽𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑞subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗\displaystyle-{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})% ]-\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log q(z_{mj})],- blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] , (2)

where the expectation is taken over the joint variational distribution in Eq. 1.

Likelihood with Continuous Word Counts. One key difference between VALC and typical topic models (Blei et al., 2003; Blei, 2012) is the virtual continuous (real-valued) word counts (discussed in Sec. 3.3). Specifically, we define the likelihood in the third term of Eq. 2 as:

p⁢(𝐞m⁢j|zm⁢j,𝝁zm⁢j,𝚺zm⁢j)=[𝒩⁢(𝐞m⁢j;𝝁m⁢j,𝚺m⁢j)]wm⁢j.𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝚺subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗superscriptdelimited-[]𝒩subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑚𝑗subscript𝚺𝑚𝑗subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗\displaystyle p({\bf e}_{mj}|z_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},% \mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})=[{\mathcal{N}}({\bf e}_{mj};% \mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{mj}% )]^{w_{mj}}.italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = [ caligraphic_N ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (3)

Note that Eq. 3 is the likelihood of wm⁢jsubscript𝑤𝑚𝑗w_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (virtual) words, where wm⁢jsubscript𝑤𝑚𝑗w_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a real value derived from the FLM’s attention weights (details in Sec. 3.3). Therefore, in the third item of Eq. 2, we have:

𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝐞m⁢j|zm⁢j,𝝁zm⁢j,𝚺zm⁢j)]subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝚺subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|z_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
=\displaystyle=~{}= ∑kϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j⁢log⁡𝒩⁢(𝐞m⁢j|𝝁k,𝚺k)subscript𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗𝒩conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{{k}}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\log{\mathcal{N}}({\bf e}_{mj}% |\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log caligraphic_N ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
=\displaystyle=~{}= ∑kϕm⁢j⁢kwm⁢j{−12(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)T𝚺k−1(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{{k}}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\{-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{mj}-% \mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{% k}^{-1}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
−log[(2π)d/2|𝚺k|1/2]}.\displaystyle-\log[(2\pi)^{d/2}|\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}% ]\}.- roman_log [ ( 2 italic_π ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] } . (4)

Update Rules. Taking the derivative of the ELBO in Eq. 2 w.r.t. ϕm⁢j⁢ksubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘\phi_{mjk}italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see Appendix A for details) and setting it to 00 yields the update rule for ϕm⁢j⁢ksubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘\phi_{mjk}italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

ϕm⁢j⁢k∝proportional-tosubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘absent\displaystyle\phi_{mjk}\propto~{}italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∝ wm⁢j|𝚺k|1/2exp[Ψ(γm⁢k)−Ψ(∑k′γm⁢k′)\displaystyle\tfrac{w_{mj}}{|\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}}% \exp[\Psi(\gamma_{mk})-\Psi(\sum\nolimits_{k^{\prime}}\gamma_{mk^{\prime}})divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG | bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_exp [ roman_Ψ ( italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Ψ ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
−12(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)T𝚺k−1(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)],\displaystyle-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^% {T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$% \mu$\unboldmath}_{k})],- divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] , (5)

with the normalization constraint ∑k=1Kϕm⁢j⁢k=1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘1\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{mjk}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1.

γm⁢k=αk+∑j=1Jmϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j,subscript𝛾𝑚𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗\displaystyle\gamma_{mk}=\alpha_{k}+\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj},italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (6)

where 𝜶≜[αk]k=1K≜𝜶superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝛼𝑘𝑘1𝐾\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath}\triangleq[\alpha_{k}]_{k=1}^{K}bold_italic_α ≜ [ italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the hyperparameter for the Dirichlet prior distribution of 𝜽msubscript𝜽𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In summary, the inference algorithm will alternate between updating ϕm⁢j⁢ksubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘\phi_{mjk}italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all (m,j,k)𝑚𝑗𝑘(m,j,k)( italic_m , italic_j , italic_k ) tuples and updating 𝜸m⁢ksubscript𝜸𝑚𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{mk}bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all (m,k)𝑚𝑘(m,k)( italic_m , italic_k ) tuples.

3.4.2 Learning

Learning Dataset-Level Concept Parameters. The inference algorithm in Sec. 3.4.1 assumes availability of the dataset-level (global) concept parameters {(𝝁k,𝚺k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To learn these parameters, one needs to iterate between (1) inferring document-level variational parameters 𝜸msubscript𝜸𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as well as word-level variational parameters ϕm⁢jsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Sec. 3.4.1 and (2) learning dataset-level concept parameters {(𝝁k,𝚺k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Update Rules. Similar to Sec. 3.4.1, we expand the ELBO in Eq. 2 (see Appendix A for details) and set its derivative w.r.t. 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to 𝟎0{\bf 0}bold_0, yielding the update rule for learning 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

𝝁k=subscript𝝁𝑘absent\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}=~{}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑m,jϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j⁢𝐞m⁢j∑m,jϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j,subscript𝑚𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝑚𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗\displaystyle\tfrac{\sum_{m,j}{\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}{\bf e}_{mj}}}{\sum_{m,j}\phi_{% mjk}w_{mj}},divide start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ,
𝚺k=subscript𝚺𝑘absent\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}=~{}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑m,jϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j⁢(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)⁢(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)T∑m,jϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j.subscript𝑚𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘𝑇subscript𝑚𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗\displaystyle\tfrac{\sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$% \mu$\unboldmath}_{k})({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}}{% \sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}}.divide start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . (7)

Effect of Attention Weights. From Eq. 7, we can observe that the attention weight of the j𝑗jitalic_j’th word in document m𝑚mitalic_m, i.e., am⁢jsubscript𝑎𝑚𝑗a_{mj}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, affects the virtual continuous word count wm⁢jsubscript𝑤𝑚𝑗w_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see Sec. 3.3), thereby affecting the update of the dataset-level concept center 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and covariance 𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Specifically, if we use attention-based weights with fixed length or variable length in Sec. 3.3, the continuous word count wm⁢jsubscript𝑤𝑚𝑗w_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be proportional to the attention weight am⁢jsubscript𝑎𝑚𝑗a_{mj}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, when updating the concept center 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as a weighted average of different word embeddings 𝐞m⁢jsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗{\bf e}_{mj}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, VALC naturally places more focus on words with higher attention weights am⁢jsubscript𝑎𝑚𝑗a_{mj}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from FLMs, thereby making the interpretations sharper (see Sec. 5.4 for detailed results and Appendix I for theoretical analysis).

4 Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we provide theoretical guarantees of VALC on the four properties in Definition 3.1.

Multi-Level Structure. As shown in Alg. 1, VALC (1) learns the dataset-level interpretation {𝛀k}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛀𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$\unboldmath}_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}{ bold_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT describing the K𝐾Kitalic_K concepts, (2) infers the distribution of document-level interpretation 𝜽msubscript𝜽𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for document m𝑚mitalic_m, i.e., q⁢(𝜽m|𝜸m)𝑞conditionalsubscript𝜽𝑚subscript𝜸𝑚q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {m})italic_q ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (parameterized by 𝜸msubscript𝜸𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), and (3) infers the posterior distribution of word-level concept index, i.e., q⁢(zm⁢j|ϕm⁢j)𝑞conditionalsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗q(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), parameterized by ϕm⁢jsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Such three-level interpretations correspond to Property (1) in Definition 3.1.

Normalization. The learned variational distribution q⁢(𝜽m|𝜸m)𝑞conditionalsubscript𝜽𝑚subscript𝜸𝑚q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {m})italic_q ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (described in Eq. 1) is a Dirichlet distribution; therefore we have ∑k=1Kθm⁢k=1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜃𝑚𝑘1\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{mk}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. The update of ϕm⁢jsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Eq. 3.4.1) is naturally constrained by ∑k=1Kϕm⁢j⁢k=1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘1\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{mjk}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 since ϕm⁢jsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT parameterizes a Categorical distribution (over zm⁢jsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗z_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).

Additivity. VALC is able to perform Concept Editing, i.e, add/subtract the learned concept activation μksubscript𝜇𝑘\mu_{k}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from FLMs via the following Quadratic Programming (QP) problem (𝐱=[xk]k=1K𝐱superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑥𝑘𝑘1𝐾{\bf x}=[x_{k}]_{k=1}^{K}bold_x = [ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT):

min𝐱∈ℝKsubscript𝐱superscriptℝ𝐾\displaystyle\min\nolimits_{{\bf x}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}}\quadroman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‖∑k=1Kxk⁢𝝁k−𝐞m‖2,superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝐞𝑚2\displaystyle\|\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}x_{k}\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k% }-{\bf e}_{m}\|^{2},∥ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,
subject to 𝐱≥𝟎⁢ and ⁢∑k=1Kxk=1.𝐱0 and superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑥𝑘1\displaystyle{\bf x}\geq{\bf 0}\mbox{~{}~{}and~{}~{}}\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}x_% {k}=1.bold_x ≥ bold_0 and ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 . (8)

Given learned concepts {(𝝁k,𝚺k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, VALC obtains this QP’s optimal solution 𝐱∗∈ℝKsuperscript𝐱superscriptℝ𝐾{\bf x}^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and add/subtract any concept k𝑘kitalic_k from arbitrary FLM embedding 𝐞msubscript𝐞𝑚{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by: 𝐞m←𝐞m±xk∗⁢𝝁k.←subscript𝐞𝑚plus-or-minussubscript𝐞𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝝁𝑘{\bf e}_{m}\leftarrow{\bf e}_{m}\pm x^{*}_{k}\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_% {k}.bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ← bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ± italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Alg. 2 summarizes this concept editing process; one can also replace 𝐞m⁢jsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗{\bf e}_{mj}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the CLS embedding 𝐜msubscript𝐜𝑚{\bf c}_{m}bold_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for document-level editing (details in Appendix 3).

Mutual Information Maximization. Theorem 4.1 below shows that our inferred document-level and word-level interpretation, 𝜽msubscript𝜽𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and {ϕm⁢j}j=1Jmsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{ bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, satisfy Property (4), Mutual Information Maximization, in Definition 3.1.

Theorem 4.1 (Mutual Information Maximization).

In Eq. 2, the ELBO ℒ⁢(𝛄m,{ϕm⁢j}j=1Jm;𝛂,{(𝛍k,𝚺k)}k=1K)ℒsubscript𝛄𝑚superscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚𝛂superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛍𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾\mathcal{L}(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$% \unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}};\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath},\{(\mbox% {\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=% 1}^{K})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; bold_italic_α , { ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is upper bounded by the mutual information between contextual embeddings 𝐞msubscript𝐞𝑚{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and multi-level interpretation 𝛉m,{ϕm⁢j}j=1Jmsubscript𝛉𝑚superscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{% mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in Definition 3.1. Formally, with approximate posteriors q⁢(𝛉m|𝛄m)𝑞conditionalsubscript𝛉𝑚subscript𝛄𝑚q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {m})italic_q ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and q⁢(zm⁢j|ϕm⁢j)𝑞conditionalsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscriptbold-ϕ𝑚𝑗q(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), we have

ℒℒ\displaystyle\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L (𝜸m,{ϕm⁢j}j=1Jm;𝜶,{(𝝁k,𝚺k)}k=1K)subscript𝜸𝑚superscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚𝜶superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾\displaystyle(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$% \unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}};\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath},\{(\mbox% {\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=% 1}^{K})( bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; bold_italic_α , { ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
≤\displaystyle\leq~{}≤ I⁢(𝐞m;𝜽m,{zm⁢j}j=1Jm)−H⁢(𝐞m),𝐼subscript𝐞𝑚subscript𝜽𝑚superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚𝐻subscript𝐞𝑚\displaystyle{I}({\bf e}_{m};\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m},\{z_{mj}% \}_{j=1}^{J_{m}})-H({\bf e}_{m}),italic_I ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_H ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (9)

where the entropy term H⁢(𝐞m)𝐻subscript𝐞𝑚H({\bf e}_{m})italic_H ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a constant.

From Theorem 4.1 we can see that maximizing the ELBO in Eq. 2 is equivalent to maximizing the mutual information between our document-level/word-level concepts and the observed contextual embeddings in FLMs (proof in Appendix H).

In summary, VALC enjoys all four properties in Definition 3.1 and therefore generates the optimal conceptual interpretation for FLMs. In contrast, state-of-the-art methods only satisfy a small part of them (Table 1 and Sec. 5.2). In Appendix I, we provide theoretical guarantees that (1) under mild assumptions our VALC can learn better conceptual interpretations for FLMs for in noisy data and (2) attention-based schemes is superior to the identical scheme (described in Sec. 3.3).

5 Experiments

5.1 Experiment Setup

Datasets. We use three datasets in our experiments, namely 20 Newsgroups, M10 (Lim and Buntine, 2015), and BBC News (Greene and Cunningham, 2006). For preprocessing details, see Appendix C.

Baselines. We compare our method with the following state-of-the-art baselines:

  • •

    SHAP and LIME (Lundberg and Lee, 2017; Ribeiro et al., 2016) are interpretation methods that attribute importance scores to input features. In this paper, we use embeddings of ‘CLS’ token as input to SHAP/LIME.

  • •

    BERTopic (Grootendorst, 2020) is a clustering-based model that uses HDBSCAN (McInnes and Healy, 2017) to cluster sentence embeddings from BERT, performs Uniform Manifold Approximation Projection (UMAP) (McInnes et al., 2018), and then uses class-based TF-IDF (c-TF-IDF) to obtain words for each cluster.

  • •

    CETopic (Zhang et al., 2022) is a clustering-based model that first uses UMAP to perform dimensionality reduction on BERT sentence embeddings, performs K-Means clustering (Lloyd, 1982), and then uses weighted word selection for each cluster.

Evaluation Metric. Inspired by Koh et al. (2020), we perform concept editing experiments to evaluate conceptual interpretation for FLMs; higher accuracy gain after editing indicates better interpretation performance. We leverage BERT-base-uncased (Devlin et al., 2018) as the contextual embedding model, and use accuracy on the test set as our metric. For a fair comparison, we adhered to the baseline methodologies (e.g., BERTopic and CETopic) by setting the number of concepts (topics) K𝐾Kitalic_K to 100 across all datasets. This number was chosen as it strikes an effective balance between capturing adequate detail and avoiding model overfitting. See Appendix D for more details.

We can perform concept editing on either input tokens or contextual embeddings of FLMs. Specifically, we can perform hard concept editing for concept k𝑘kitalic_k by directly removing tokens that belong concept k𝑘kitalic_k (applicable for hard clustering methods such as our baselines); we could also perform soft concept editing for concept k𝑘kitalic_k by removing concept subspace vectors from contextual embeddings 𝐞msubscript𝐞𝑚{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (applicable for VALC using Alg. 2).

Following Lyu et al. (2024), we conducted additional experiments to evaluate the faithfulness metric. The faithfulness metric is implemented as the accuracy score of predictions using logistic regression, with the inferred conceptual explanations as inputs.

5.2 Comparison on Four Properties in Definition 3.1

In Sec. 4 we show that VALC satisfies the four properties of conceptual interpretation in Definition 3.1. In contrast, baseline models do not necessarily learn concepts that meet these requirements. Table 1 summarizes the comparison between VALC and the baselines. We can see that VALC is superior to baselines in terms of the following four aspects:

  1. (1)

    Multi-Level Structure. Baselines either apply clustering algorithms directly on the document-level embeddings from FLMs or assign importance scores to input features, and thus can only provide single-level interpretation, necessitating complex post-processing to generate dataset-level concepts. In contrast, VALC adopts an integrated approach, learning concepts at the dataset, document, and word level in a joint, end-to-end manner.

  2. (2)

    Normalization. BERTopic and CETopic assign each word to exactly one concept and therefore satisfies hard-normalization. SHAP/LIME produce importance scores that are not normalized. In contrast, VALC learns fractional concept interpretations 𝜸msubscript𝜸𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ϕm⁢jsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and therefore satisfies soft-normalization, which is more flexible and intuitive.

  3. (3)

    Additivity. Baselines perform addition or subtraction of concepts only at a single level (word/document), while our additivity and concept editing (Alg. 2) work for both levels.

  4. (4)

    Mutual Information Maximization. Baselines either use a multi-step pipeline or produce importance scores; they are therefore prone to lose information between FLM embeddings and final clustering/scoring results. In contrast, VALC is theoretically guaranteed to maximally preserve information (Theorem 4.1).

5.3 Results

Accuracy Gain. We perform greedy concept editing (Koh et al., 2020) for BERTopic, CETopic, and our VALC to evaluate the quality of their learned concepts. Higher accuracy gain after pruning indicates better performance.

Table 2 show the results for different methods in three real-world datasets, where ‘Finetune (Oracle)’ refers to finetuning both the backbone and the classifier of BERT. VALC’s concept editing can improve the accuracy upon the unedited model by more than 11%percent1111\%11 % in 20 Newsgroups and M10, almost on par with ‘Finetune (Oracle)’. Compared with the baselines, VALC achieves the most accuracy gain in 20 Newsgroups and M10 and the second most accuracy gain in BBC News, demonstrating the effectiveness of VALC’s four properties in Definition 3.1. Note that SHAP and LIME both interpret the CLS token’s embedding and therefore has identical accuracy gain (details in Appendix D).

Ablation Study. Thanks to its full additivity (Definition 3.1), VALC is capable of different concept editing schemes, including ‘Random’, ‘Unweighted’, and ‘Weighted’. Specifically, weighted pruning uses the concept editing algorithm in Alg. 2 with the optimal hyperparameter ω𝜔\omegaitalic_ω; unweighted pruning runs Alg. 2 with ω=1𝜔1\omega=1italic_ω = 1; random pruning first randomly picks a concept k𝑘kitalic_k (k∈{1,…,K}𝑘1…𝐾k\in\{1,...,K\}italic_k ∈ { 1 , … , italic_K }), sets ω⋅xk=1/K⋅𝜔subscript𝑥𝑘1𝐾\omega\cdot x_{k}=1/Kitalic_ω ⋅ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 / italic_K, and then runs Alg. 2.

Table 3 shows accuracy for VALC’s different schemes. As expected, random pruning barely improves upon the unedited model. Unweighted pruning improves upon the unedited model by 1.5∼3.5%similar-to1.5percent3.51.5\sim 3.5\%1.5 ∼ 3.5 %. Weighted pruning improves the accuracy by around 11%percent1111\%11 % upon the unedited model on 20 Newsgroups and M10.

Faithfulness. Table 4 shows the faithfulness of VALC and baselines on the 20 Newsgroups, M10, and BBC News datasets. These results show that our VALC significantly outperforms the baseline models, achieving the highest faithfulness accuracy scores in the 20 Newsgroups (89.8%percent89.889.8\%89.8 %), M10 (99.5%percent99.599.5\%99.5 %), and BBC News (100.0%percent100.0100.0\%100.0 %) datasets.

Note that the dataset size of 20 Newsgroups, M10, and BBC News is 16,3091630916{,}30916 , 309, 8,35583558{,}3558 , 355, and 2,22522252{,}2252 , 225, respectively. BBC News contains significantly less data, making it easier to achieve a high faithfulness score. This explains why both CETopic and our VALC obtain a faithfulness score of 100.0%percent100.0100.0\%100.0 %.

Baseline methods such as BERTopic and CETopic represent language concepts as discrete bags of words, which lack flexibility and accuracy. In contrast, VALC infers continuous concepts for datasets, documents, and words with theoretical guarantees. Consequently, it provides optimal and faithful conceptual explanations of high quality.

See Appendix G for more quantitative results.

5.4 Conceptual Interpretation (More for Different Tasks in Appendix F)

Dataset-Level Interpretations. As a case study, we train VALC on M10, sample 6666 concepts (topics) from the dataset, and plot the word embeddings of the top words (closest to the center 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) in these concepts using PCA in Fig. 4(left and middle). We can observe Concept 5 is mostly about data analysis, including words such as ‘sampling’ and ‘similarity’. Concept 84 is mostly about reasoning, with words ‘explore’, ’accept’, ‘explain’, etc. Concept 62 is mostly about nature, with words ‘environment’, ‘formation’, ‘growth’, etc. Concept 98 is mostly about farming, with words ‘term’, ‘summer’, ‘heating’, etc. Concept 24 is mostly about economics, with words ‘forthcoming’, ‘prospect’, ‘grow’, etc. Concept 74 is mostly about social contact, containing words such as ‘peer’, ‘connect’, and ‘collaborative’. Interestingly, Concept 24 (economics) and Concept 74 (social contact) are both related to social science and are therefore closer to each other in Fig. 4(middle), while Concept 98 (farming) is farther away, showing VALC’s cability of capturing concept similarity.

Document-Level Interpretations. Fig. 4(right) shows that VALC can provide conceptual interpretations on why correct or incorrect FLM predictions happen for specific documents. For example, document (e) belongs to class 2 (biology), but BERT misclassifies it as class 9 (social science); our VALC interprets that this is because document (e) involves Concept 24 (economics), which is related to social science. On the other hand, document (b) is related to machine learning and BERT correctly classifies it as class 3 (computer science); VALC interprets that this is because document (b) involves Concept 5 (data analysis).

Word-Level Interpretations. Fig. 4(right) also shows that VALC can interpret which words and what concepts of these words lead to specific FLM predictions. For example, document (f) belongs to class 7 (petroleum chemistry), but BERT misclassifies it as class 0 (agriculture); VALC attributes this to the word ‘air’, which belongs to Concept 98 (farming). For document (b), VALC interprets that BERT correctly classifies it as class 3 (computer science) because the document contains the word ‘kernel’ that belongs to Concept 5 (data analysis).

6 Conclusion

We address the challenge of multi-level interpretations for FLM predictions by defining conceptual interpretation and introducing VALC, the first method to infer such interpretations effectively. Empirical results are promising, and theoretical analysis confirms that VALC reliably produces optimal conceptual interpretations by our definition.

7 Limitations

Our proposed method assumes access to the hidden layers of Transformer-based models, and therefore can be naturally extended to Transformer-based models including RoBERTa Liu et al. (2019), DeBERTa He et al. (2021), ALBERT Lan et al. (2019), Electra Clark et al. (2020), and decoder-only models, such as GPTs Radford et al. (2019); Brown (2020). Although our VALC is initially designed for Transformer-based models, it is also generalizable to other architectures, such as Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) LeCun et al. (2015) and Long Short-Term Memory networks (LSTMs) Hochreiter and Schmidhuber (1997), by simply setting identical attention weights. Future work may include extending VALC beyond Transformer variants and natural language applications. However, many other foundation language models provided by proprietary sources may not expose their internal states, limiting the applicability of our method in such cases.

8 Ethical Considerations

VALC, as the first to comprehensively interpret FLMs at the concept level, holds significant promise for advancing societal and technological progress. By elucidating the inner workings of these complex FLMs, we enable greater transparency and trust in AI systems, which is crucial for their widespread adoption. This transparency ensures that AI-driven decisions in critical areas such as healthcare, law, and finance are more explainable and accountable, thus safeguarding against biases and errors. Additionally, our VALC fosters enhanced collaboration between AI and human experts, as interpretable models can provide insights that are more easily understood and acted upon by domain specialists.
