This symbiotic relationship has the potential to accelerate innovation, improve decision-making processes, and ultimately lead to more ethical and equitable AI applications, thereby benefiting society at large.

9 Acknowledgements

We extend our sincere gratitude to Akshay Nambi and Tanuja Ganu from Microsoft Research for their invaluable insights and guidance, which significantly enhanced the quality of this work. We also express our deep appreciation to Microsoft Research AI & Society Fellowship, NSF Grant IIS-2127918, NSF CAREER Award IIS-2340125, NIH Grant 1R01CA297832, and the Amazon Faculty Research Award for their generous support. This research is also supported by NSF National Artificial Intelligence Research Resource (NAIRR) Pilot and the Frontera supercomputer supported by the National Science Foundation (award NSF-OAC 1818253) at the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) at The University of Texas at Austin. Additionally, we thank the anonymous reviewers and the area chair/senior area chair for their thoughtful feedback and for recognizing the significance and contributions of our research. Finally, we would like to thank the Center for AI Safety (CAIS) for providing the essential computing resources that enabled this work.

  • Liu et al. (2019) Yinhan Liu, Myle Ott, Naman Goyal, Jingfei Du, Mandar Joshi, Danqi Chen, Omer Levy, Mike Lewis, Luke Zettlemoyer, and Veselin Stoyanov. 2019. Roberta: A robustly optimized bert pretraining approach. arXiv preprint arXiv:1907.11692.

Appendix A Details on Learning VALC

Update Rules. Similar to Sec. 3.4.1 of the main paper, we expand the ELBO in Eq. 2 of the main paper, take its derivative w.r.t. 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and set it to 𝟎0{\bf 0}bold_0:

∂L∂𝝁k=∑m,jϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j⁢𝚺k−1⁢(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)=0,𝐿subscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝑚𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑘1subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘0\displaystyle\tfrac{\partial L}{\partial\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}}=% \sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1}({\bf e}% _{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})=0,divide start_ARG ∂ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG ∂ bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0 , (10)

yielding the update rule for learning 𝝁isubscript𝝁𝑖\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{i}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =∑m,jϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j⁢𝐞m⁢j∑m,jϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j,absentsubscript𝑚𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝑚𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗\displaystyle=\tfrac{\sum_{m,j}{\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}{\bf e}_{mj}}}{\sum_{m,j}\phi_% {mjk}w_{mj}},= divide start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , (11)

where 𝚺k−1superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑘1\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is canceled out. Similarly, setting the derivatives w.r.t. 𝚺𝚺\Sigmabold_Σ to 𝟎0{\bf 0}bold_0, i.e.,

∂L∂𝚺k=12⁢∑m,jϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j⁢(−𝚺k−1+𝚺k−1⁢(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)⁢(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)T⁢𝚺k−1),𝐿subscript𝚺𝑘12subscript𝑚𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑘1subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘𝑇superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑘1\displaystyle\tfrac{\partial L}{\partial\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% }}=\tfrac{1}{2}\sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}(-\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}% _{k}^{-1}+\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_% {k})^{T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1}),divide start_ARG ∂ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG ∂ bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( - bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (12)

we have

𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =∑m,jϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j⁢(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)⁢(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)T∑m,jϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j.absentsubscript𝑚𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘𝑇subscript𝑚𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗\displaystyle=\tfrac{\sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$% \mu$\unboldmath}_{k})({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}}{% \sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}}.= divide start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . (13)

Smoothing with Prior Distributions on {(μk,𝚺k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To alleviate overfitting and prevent singularity in numerical computation, we impose priors distributions on 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to smooth the learning process (Fig. 5). Specifically, we use a Normal-Inverse-Wishart prior on 𝝁isubscript𝝁𝑖\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{i}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝚺isubscript𝚺𝑖\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{i}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ℐ⁢𝒲⁢(𝚲0,ν0),similar-toabsentℐ𝒲subscript𝚲0subscript𝜈0\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{IW}(\mbox{\boldmath$\Lambda$\unboldmath}_{0},\nu_{0}),∼ caligraphic_I caligraphic_W ( bold_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,
𝝁k|𝚺kconditionalsubscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}|\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼𝒩⁢(𝝁0,𝚺k/κ0),similar-toabsent𝒩subscript𝝁0subscript𝚺𝑘subscript𝜅0\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{0},\mbox{% \boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}/\kappa_{0}),∼ caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

where 𝚲0subscript𝚲0\mbox{\boldmath$\Lambda$\unboldmath}_{0}bold_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ν0subscript𝜈0\nu_{0}italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝝁0subscript𝝁0\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{0}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and κ0subscript𝜅0\kappa_{0}italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are hyperparameters for the prior distributions. Taking the expectations of 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over the posterior distibution 𝒩⁢ℐ⁢𝒲⁢(𝝁k,𝚺k|𝝁k(n),𝚲k(n),κk(n),νk(n))𝒩ℐ𝒲subscript𝝁𝑘conditionalsubscript𝚺𝑘superscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝚲𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜅𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑛\mathcal{NIW}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k}|\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}^{(n)},\mbox{\boldmath$% \Lambda$\unboldmath}_{k}^{(n)},\kappa_{k}^{(n)},\nu_{k}^{(n)})caligraphic_N caligraphic_I caligraphic_W ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), we have the update rules as:

𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ←𝔼𝒩⁢ℐ⁢𝒲⁢[𝝁k]=κ0⁢𝝁0+nk⁢𝝁~kκ0+nk,←absentsubscript𝔼𝒩ℐ𝒲delimited-[]subscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝜅0subscript𝝁0subscript𝑛𝑘subscript~𝝁𝑘subscript𝜅0subscript𝑛𝑘\displaystyle\leftarrow{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{NIW}}[\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}_{k}]=\tfrac{\kappa_{0}\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{0}+n_{k}% \widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k}}{\kappa_{0}+n_{k}},← blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N caligraphic_I caligraphic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = divide start_ARG italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_italic_μ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , (14)
𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ←𝔼𝒩⁢ℐ⁢𝒲⁢[𝚺k]=𝚲0+𝐒k+κ0⁢nkκ0+nk⁢(𝝁~k−𝝁0)⁢(𝝁~k−𝝁0)Tν0+nk−K−1,←absentsubscript𝔼𝒩ℐ𝒲delimited-[]subscript𝚺𝑘subscript𝚲0subscript𝐒𝑘subscript𝜅0subscript𝑛𝑘subscript𝜅0subscript𝑛𝑘subscript~𝝁𝑘subscript𝝁0superscriptsubscript~𝝁𝑘subscript𝝁0𝑇subscript𝜈0subscript𝑛𝑘𝐾1\displaystyle\leftarrow{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{NIW}}[\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k}]=\tfrac{\mbox{\boldmath$\Lambda$\unboldmath}_{0}+{\bf S}_{k}+% \tfrac{\kappa_{0}n_{k}}{\kappa_{0}+n_{k}}(\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}}_{k}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{0})(\widetilde{\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{0})^{T}}{\nu% _{0}+n_{k}-K-1},← blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N caligraphic_I caligraphic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = divide start_ARG bold_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( over~ start_ARG bold_italic_μ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( over~ start_ARG bold_italic_μ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K - 1 end_ARG , (15)
𝐒ksubscript𝐒𝑘\displaystyle{\bf S}_{k}bold_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =∑m,jϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j⁢(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁~k)⁢(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁~k)T.absentsubscript𝑚𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript~𝝁𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript~𝝁𝑘𝑇\displaystyle=\sum\nolimits_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}({\bf e}_{mj}-\widetilde{% \mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k})({\bf e}_{mj}-\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath% $\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k})^{T}.= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_μ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_μ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (16)

where nk=∑m,jϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢jsubscript𝑛𝑘subscript𝑚𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗n_{k}=\sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the total virtual word counts used to estimate 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Eq. 14 and Eq. 15 are the smoothed version of Eq. 7 of the main paper. From the Bayesian perfective, they correspond to the expectations of 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s and 𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s posterior distributions. Alg. 1 of the main paper summarizes the learning of VALC.

Online Learning of μksubscript𝜇𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that FLMs are deep neural networks trained using minibatches of data, while Eq. 14 and Eq. 15 need to go through the whole dataset before each update. Inspired by Hoffman et al. (2010); Oord et al. (2017), we using exponential moving average (EMA) to work with minibatchs. Specifically, we update them as:

𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ←ρ⋅N⋅𝝁k+(1−ρ)⋅B⋅𝝁~k,←absent⋅𝜌𝑁subscript𝝁𝑘⋅1𝜌𝐵subscript~𝝁𝑘\displaystyle\leftarrow\rho\cdot N\cdot\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}+(1% -\rho)\cdot B\cdot\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k},← italic_ρ ⋅ italic_N ⋅ bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_ρ ) ⋅ italic_B ⋅ over~ start_ARG bold_italic_μ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,
𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ←ρ⋅N⋅𝚺k+(1−ρ)⋅B⋅𝚺~k,←absent⋅𝜌𝑁subscript𝚺𝑘⋅1𝜌𝐵subscript~𝚺𝑘\displaystyle\leftarrow\rho\cdot N\cdot\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}% +(1-\rho)\cdot B\cdot\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}}_{k},← italic_ρ ⋅ italic_N ⋅ bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_ρ ) ⋅ italic_B ⋅ over~ start_ARG bold_Σ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,
N𝑁\displaystyle Nitalic_N ←ρ⋅N+(1−ρ)⋅B,←absent⋅𝜌𝑁⋅1𝜌𝐵\displaystyle\leftarrow\rho\cdot N+(1-\rho)\cdot B,← italic_ρ ⋅ italic_N + ( 1 - italic_ρ ) ⋅ italic_B ,
𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ←𝝁kN,𝚺k←𝚺kN,formulae-sequence←absentsubscript𝝁𝑘𝑁←subscript𝚺𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘𝑁\displaystyle\leftarrow\tfrac{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}}{N},\quad% \mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}\leftarrow\tfrac{\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma% $\unboldmath}_{k}}{N},← divide start_ARG bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ← divide start_ARG bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ,

where B𝐵Bitalic_B is the minibatch size, N𝑁Nitalic_N is a running count, and ρ∈(0,1)𝜌01\rho\in(0,1)italic_ρ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) is the momentum hyperparameter. 𝝁~ksubscript~𝝁𝑘\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_μ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝚺~ksubscript~𝚺𝑘\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}}_{k}over~ start_ARG bold_Σ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the updated 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT after applying Eq. 14 and Eq. 15 only on the current minibatch.

Effect of Attention Weights. Interestingly, we also observe that FLMs’ attention weights on stop words such as ‘the’ and ‘a’ tend to be much lower; therefore VALC can naturally ignore these concept-irrelevant stop words when learning and inferring concepts (as discussed in Sec. 3.4.2). This is in contrast to typical topic models (Blei et al., 2003; Blei, 2012) that require preprocessing to remove stop words.

Phrase-Level Interpretations. We can easily infer phrase-level concepts from word-level concepts by treating phrases as sub-documents and adapting Eq. 6 (which provides document-level concepts) in the paper. Specifically, suppose for a given phrase spanning from the r𝑟ritalic_r-th word to the s𝑠sitalic_s-th word in document m𝑚mitalic_m, we can adapt Eq. 6 to provide phrase-level conceptual explanations as γm⁢k(r,s)=αk+∑j=rsϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢jsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑠subscript𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑟𝑠subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗\gamma_{mk}^{(r,s)}=\alpha_{k}+\sum_{j=r}^{s}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r , italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Here γm⁢k(r,s)superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑠\gamma_{mk}^{(r,s)}italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r , italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the strength of concept k𝑘kitalic_k for the given phrase in document m𝑚mitalic_m. In this way, γm⁢k(r,s)superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑚𝑘𝑟𝑠\gamma_{mk}^{(r,s)}italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r , italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can serve as the phrase-level concept explanation of the phrase spanning from r𝑟ritalic_r-th word to the s𝑠sitalic_s-th word; this is another interesting complementary sub-document-level concept explanation between the word level and the document level.

Appendix B Interpretation of the ELBO

VALC’s evidence lower bound (ELBO), i.e., Eq. 2 in the paper, is

ℒ⁢(𝜸m,{ϕm⁣[1:Jm]};α,{(𝝁[1:K],𝚺[1:K])})ℒsubscript𝜸𝑚subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚delimited-[]:1subscript𝐽𝑚𝛼subscript𝝁delimited-[]:1𝐾subscript𝚺delimited-[]:1𝐾\displaystyle\mathcal{L}(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{% \boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{m[1:J_{m}]}\};\alpha,\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}_{[1:K]},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{[1:K]})\})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m [ 1 : italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ; italic_α , { ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 1 : italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 1 : italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } ) =𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝜽m|α)]+∑j=1Jm𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝐳m⁢j|𝜽m)]absentsubscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝜽𝑚𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐳𝑚𝑗subscript𝜽𝑚\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|% \alpha)]+\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log p({\bf z}_{mj}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})]= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_α ) ] + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
+∑j=1Jm𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝐞m⁢j|𝐳m⁢j,μ𝐳m⁢j,Σ𝐳m⁢j)]superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝐳𝑚𝑗subscript𝜇subscript𝐳𝑚𝑗subscriptΣsubscript𝐳𝑚𝑗\displaystyle+\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|{% \bf z}_{mj},\mu_{{\bf z}_{mj}},\Sigma_{{\bf z}_{mj}})]+ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
−𝔼q⁢[log⁡q⁢(𝜽m)]−∑j=1Jm𝔼q⁢[log⁡q⁢(𝐳m⁢j)].subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑞subscript𝜽𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑞subscript𝐳𝑚𝑗\displaystyle-\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})]-% \sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log q({\bf z}_{mj})].- blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] . (17)

Derivation of the Evidence Lower Bound. We derive the evidence lower bound by computing the log likelihood of each term. For example, by definition, p⁢(𝐞m⁢j|𝐳m⁢j,μ𝐳m⁢j,Σ𝐳m⁢j)=[𝒩⁢(𝐞m⁢j;𝝁m⁢j,𝚺m⁢j)]wm⁢j𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝐳𝑚𝑗subscript𝜇subscript𝐳𝑚𝑗subscriptΣsubscript𝐳𝑚𝑗superscriptdelimited-[]𝒩subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑚𝑗subscript𝚺𝑚𝑗subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗p({\bf e}_{mj}|{\bf z}_{mj},\mu_{{\bf z}_{mj}},\Sigma_{{\bf z}_{mj}})=[% \mathcal{N}({\bf e}_{mj};\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath% $\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{mj})]^{w_{mj}}italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = [ caligraphic_N ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where 𝒩⁢(⋅)𝒩⋅\mathcal{N}(\cdot)caligraphic_N ( ⋅ ) is the Gaussian distribution. Then we derive the third term ∑j=1Jm𝔼𝕢⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝐞m⁢j|𝐳m⁢j,μ𝐳m⁢j,Σ𝐳m⁢j)]superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚subscript𝔼𝕢delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝐳𝑚𝑗subscript𝜇subscript𝐳𝑚𝑗subscriptΣsubscript𝐳𝑚𝑗\sum_{j=1}^{J_{m}}\mathbb{E_{q}}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|{\bf z}_{mj},\mu_{{\bf z}% _{mj}},\Sigma_{{\bf z}_{mj}})]∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] in Eq. B as follows:

𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝐞m⁢j|𝐳m⁢j,μ𝐳m⁢j,𝚺𝐳m⁢j)]subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝐳𝑚𝑗subscript𝜇subscript𝐳𝑚𝑗subscript𝚺subscript𝐳𝑚𝑗\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|{\bf z}_{mj},\mu_{{\bf z}_{mj}% },\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{{\bf z}_{mj}})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] =∑kϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j⁢log⁡𝒩⁢(𝐞m⁢j|𝝁k,𝚺k)absentsubscript𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗𝒩conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘\displaystyle=\sum_{k}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\log\mathcal{N}({\bf e}_{mj}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log caligraphic_N ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
=∑kϕm⁢j⁢kwm⁢j{−12(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)T𝚺k−1(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)\displaystyle=\sum_{k}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\{-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1% }({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
−log[(2π)d/2|𝚺k|1/2]}.\displaystyle-\log[(2\pi)^{d/2}|\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}% ]\}.- roman_log [ ( 2 italic_π ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] } . (18)

Expanding the ELBO to the Loss Function. We can expand the ELBO in Eq. 2 of the main paper as:

ℒ⁢(𝜸,ϕ;𝜶,{𝝁}k=1K,{𝚺}k=1K)=ℒ𝜸bold-italic-ϕ𝜶superscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑘1𝐾absent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath},\mbox{\boldmath$% \phi$\unboldmath};\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}\}_{k=1}^{K},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}\}_{k=1}^{K})=caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_γ , bold_italic_ϕ ; bold_italic_α , { bold_italic_μ } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , { bold_Σ } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = log⁡𝚪⁢(∑k=1Kαk)−∑k=1Klog⁡𝚪⁢(αk)+∑k=1K(αk−1)⁢(Ψ⁢(𝜸k)−Ψ⁢(∑k′=1K𝜸k′))𝚪superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝚪subscript𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘1Ψsubscript𝜸𝑘Ψsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑘′1𝐾subscript𝜸superscript𝑘′\displaystyle\log\mbox{\boldmath$\Gamma$\unboldmath}(\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k})% -\sum_{k=1}^{K}\log\mbox{\boldmath$\Gamma$\unboldmath}(\alpha_{k})+\sum_{k=1}^% {K}(\alpha_{k}-1)(\Psi(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k})-\Psi(\sum_{k^{% \prime}=1}^{K}\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k^{\prime}}))roman_log bold_Γ ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log bold_Γ ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 ) ( roman_Ψ ( bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Ψ ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
+∑j=1J∑k=1Kϕj⁢k⁢(Ψ⁢(𝜸k)−Ψ⁢(∑k′=1K𝜸k′))superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑗𝑘Ψsubscript𝜸𝑘Ψsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑘′1𝐾subscript𝜸superscript𝑘′\displaystyle+\sum_{j=1}^{J}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{jk}(\Psi(\mbox{\boldmath$% \gamma$\unboldmath}_{k})-\Psi(\sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{K}\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$% \unboldmath}_{k^{\prime}}))+ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Ψ ( bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Ψ ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
+∑j,kϕj⁢k⁢wj⁢{−12⁢(𝐞j−𝝁k)T⁢𝚺k−1⁢(𝐞j−𝝁k)−log⁡[(2⁢π)d/2⁢|𝚺k|1/2]}subscript𝑗𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑗12superscriptsubscript𝐞𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘𝑇superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑘1subscript𝐞𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘superscript2𝜋𝑑2superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑘12\displaystyle+\sum_{j,k}\phi_{jk}w_{j}\{-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{j}-\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1% }({\bf e}_{j}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})-\log[(2\pi)^{d/2}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}]\}+ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_log [ ( 2 italic_π ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] }
−log⁡𝚪⁢(∑k=1K𝜸j)+∑k=1Klog⁡𝚪⁢(𝜸k)−∑k=1K(𝜸k−1)⁢(Ψ⁢(𝜸k)−Ψ⁢(∑k′=1K𝜸k′))𝚪superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜸𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝚪subscript𝜸𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜸𝑘1Ψsubscript𝜸𝑘Ψsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑘′1𝐾subscript𝜸superscript𝑘′\displaystyle-\log\mbox{\boldmath$\Gamma$\unboldmath}(\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mbox{% \boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{j})+\sum_{k=1}^{K}\log\mbox{\boldmath$\Gamma$% \unboldmath}(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k})-\sum_{k=1}^{K}(\mbox{% \boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k}-1)(\Psi(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {k})-\Psi(\sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{K}\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k^{% \prime}}))- roman_log bold_Γ ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log bold_Γ ( bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 ) ( roman_Ψ ( bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Ψ ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
−∑j=1J∑k=1Kϕj⁢k⁢log⁡ϕj⁢k.superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑗𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑗𝑘\displaystyle-\sum_{j=1}^{J}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{jk}\log\phi_{jk}.- ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (19)

Definition and Interpretation of the Loss Function. We can interpret the meaning of each term of ELBO as follows:

  • •

    Regularization Term for Document-Level Explanations. The sum of the first and the fourth terms, namely 𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝜽m|𝜶)]−𝔼q⁢[log⁡q⁢(𝜽m)]subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝜽𝑚𝜶subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑞subscript𝜽𝑚{{\mathbb{E}}}_{q}[\log p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath})]-{{\mathbb{E}}}_{q}[\log q(\mbox{\boldmath$% \theta$\unboldmath}_{m})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_α ) ] - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ], is equal to −KL(q(𝜽m)|p(𝜽m|𝜶))-KL(q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})|p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$% \unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath}))- italic_K italic_L ( italic_q ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_p ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_α ) ), which is the negation of KL Divergence between the variational posterior probability q⁢(𝜽m)𝑞subscript𝜽𝑚q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_q ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and the prior probability p⁢(𝜽m|α)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝜽𝑚𝛼p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\alpha)italic_p ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_α ) of the topic proportion 𝜽msubscript𝜽𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for document m𝑚mitalic_m. Therefore maximizing the sum of these two terms is equivalent to minimizing the KL Divergence KL(q(𝜽m)|p(𝜽m|𝜶))KL(q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})|p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$% \unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath}))italic_K italic_L ( italic_q ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_p ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_α ) ); this serves as a regularization term to make sure the inferred q⁢(𝜽m)𝑞subscript𝜽𝑚q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_q ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is close to its prior distribution p⁢(𝜽m|𝜶)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝜽𝑚𝜶p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath})italic_p ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_α ).

  • •

    Regularization Term for Word-Level Explanations. Similarly, the sum of the second and the last terms (ignoring the summation over the word index j𝑗jitalic_j for simplicity), namely 𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(zm⁢j|𝜽m)]−𝔼q⁢[log⁡q⁢(zm⁢j)]subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝜽𝑚subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑞subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗{{\mathbb{E}}_{q}}[\log p(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})]-{{% \mathbb{E}}_{q}}[\log q(z_{mj})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] is equal to −KL(q(zm⁢j)|p(zm⁢j|𝜽m))-KL(q(z_{mj})|p(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}))- italic_K italic_L ( italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ), which is the negation of the KL Divergence between the variational posterior probability q⁢(zm⁢j)𝑞subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗q(z_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and the prior probability p⁢(zm⁢j|𝜽m)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝜽𝑚p(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of the word-level topic assignment zm⁢jsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗z_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for word j𝑗jitalic_j of document m𝑚mitalic_m. Therefore maximizing the sum of these two terms is equivalent to minimizing the KL Divergence KL(q(zm⁢j)|p(zm⁢j|𝜽m))KL(q(z_{mj})|p(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}))italic_K italic_L ( italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ); this serves as a regularization term to make sure the inferred q⁢(zm⁢j)𝑞subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗q(z_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is close to its ‘prior’ distribution p⁢(zm⁢j|𝜽m)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝜽𝑚p(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

  • •

    Likelihood Term to Indicate How Much FLM Information is Explained. The third term ∑j=1Jm𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝐞m⁢j|zm⁢j,𝝁zm⁢j,𝚺zm⁢j)]superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝚺subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{{\mathbb{E}}_{q}}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|z_{mj},\mbox% {\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{z_{% mj}})]∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] is to maximize the log likelihood p⁢(𝐞m⁢j|zm⁢j,𝝁zm⁢j,𝚺zm⁢j)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝚺subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗p({\bf e}_{mj}|z_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{% \boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of every contextual embedding 𝐞m⁢jsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗{\bf e}_{mj}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (for word j𝑗jitalic_j of document m𝑚mitalic_m) conditioned on the inferred zm⁢jsubscript𝑧𝑚𝑗z_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the parameters (𝝁zm⁢j,𝚺zm⁢j)subscript𝝁subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝚺subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}% _{z_{mj}})( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

In this way, we expand the ELBO to a concrete loss function. Each line of Eq. B corresponds to the expansion of each of the five terms in the ELBO mentioned above (i.e., Eq. 2 in the paper).

Appendix C Experimental Settings and Implementation Details

We will release all code, models, and data. Below we provide more details on the experimental settings and practical implementation.

Data Preprocessing and More Datasets.

We follow Terragni et al. (2021) and Zhang et al. (2022) to pre-process these datasets. The statistics of the datasets are summarized in Table 5. We use the standard 8:1:1 train/validation/test set split. We also use the GLUE benchmark (Wang et al., 2018) to perform additional conceptual interpretation in this section and Sec. F. This benchmark includes multiple sub-tasks of predictions, with the paired sentences as inputs. In this paper, we use 4 datasets from GLUE (MRPC, RTE, STS-B, and QQP) to show contextual interpretations. Specifically, we apply VALC to multiple complex natural language understanding (NLU) tasks in the GLUE benchmark. For example, in Appendix F, we show the three-level conceptual explanations of four different tasks in the GLUE benchmark using VALC, i.e.,

  • •

    Microsoft Research Paraphrase Corpus (MRPC), where the task is paraphrase identification and semantic textual similarity,

  • •

    Recognizing Textual Entailment (RTE), where the task is to determine whether one sentence (the premise) entails another sentence (the hypothesis),

  • •

    Semantic Textual Similarity Benchmark (STS-B), where the task is to measure the degree of semantic similarity between pairs of sentences (from 0 to 5), and

  • •

    Quora Question Pairs (QQP), where the task is to classify whether one question is the duplicate of the other.

Implementation. We implemented and trained the model using PyTorch Paszke et al. (2019) on an A5000 GPU with 24GB of memory. The training duration was kept under a few hours for all datasets. We utilized the Adam optimizer Kingma and Ba (2014) with initial learning rates varying between 10−5∼10−3similar-tosuperscript105superscript10310^{-5}\sim 10^{-3}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, tailored to the specific requirements of each dataset.

Visualization Postprocessing. For better showcase the dataset-level concepts as in Fig. 4 of the main paper, we may employ simple linear transformations on the embedding of words after the aforementioned PCA step, in order to scatter all the informative words on the same figures. However, for some datasets such as STS-B, this is not necessary; therefore we do not use it for these datasets.

Topic (Concept) Identification. Inspired by Blei et al. (2003), we identify meaningful topics by listing the top-5 topics for each word, computing the inverse document frequency (IDF), and filtering out topics with the lowest IDF scores. Note that although GLUE benchmark are datasets that consists of documents with small size, making it particularly challenging for traditional topic models (such as LDA) to learn topics; interestingly our VALC can still perform well in learning the topics. We contribute this to the following observations: (1) Compared to traditional LDA using discrete word representations, VALC uses continuous word embeddings. In such a continuous space, topics learned for one word can also help neighboring words; this alleviates the sparsity issue caused by short documents and therefore learns better topics. (2) VALC’s attention-based continuous word counts further improves sample efficiency. In VALC, important words have larger attention weights and therefore larger continuous word counts. In this case, one important word in a sentence possesses statistical (sample) power equivalent to multiple words; this leads to better sample efficiency in VALC.

Computational Complexity. Our VALC introduces minimal overhead in terms of model training cost. Specifically, VALC’s computational complexity is O⁢(T⁢K⁢d2)𝑂𝑇𝐾superscript𝑑2O(TKd^{2})italic_O ( italic_T italic_K italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where T𝑇Titalic_T is the number of epochs (a small number, such as 3, is sufficient for convergence), K𝐾Kitalic_K is the number of concepts, and d𝑑ditalic_d is the dimension of the embeddings (in hidden layers). This means that VALC’s computational cost scales linearly with the number of concepts K𝐾Kitalic_K (similar to existing methods).

More NLP Tasks. VALC can be naturally applied to other NLP tasks, such as named entity recognition (NER), reading comprehension, or question answering. Specifically, these tasks involve transformer predictions from multiple positions within the context, rather than relying solely on the ‘CLS’ token. For example, NER predicts each token in the document as the beginning (‘B’) of an entity, the inside (‘I’) of entities, etc. To accommodate this and use VALC to explain each token j𝑗jitalic_j in the context, we can substitute the attention from the ‘CLS’ token with (1) the attention from the ‘CLS’ token to all tokens of the previous layer with (2) the attention from token j𝑗jitalic_j to all tokens of the previous layer in transformers (e.g., using the attention weights from the predicted label ‘B’ to all tokens of the previous layer as 𝐚msubscript𝐚𝑚{\bf a}_{m}bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in VALC). This adaptation allows VALC to maintain its explanatory power across various NLP applications, demonstrating its versatility and effectiveness in a wide range of tasks.

Appendix D More Details on Concept Editing

We perform concept pruning to the CLS embeddings for VALC (details in Alg. 2). Since BERTopic and CETopic can infer concepts (topics) only at the document level, their only choice is to prune a concept by completely removing input tokens assigned to the concept (as mentioned in Sec. 5.1 and 5.2). To compare our learned concepts with the baseline models, we first follow their configurations (Grootendorst, 2020; Zhang et al., 2022) to fix BERT model parameters when learning the topics/concepts, train a classifier on top of the fixed contextual embeddings, and then perform concept pruning (Koh et al., 2020) for different evaluated models on the same classifier. Note that concept editing is deterministic; therefore, we conduct our experiments with a single run.

Specifically, we assume each BERT model contains a backbone and a classifier. To perform concept editing:

  • (1)

    We first train a classifier on top of the fixed BERT embeddings generated by the fixed backbone to get the original accuracy in the ‘Unedited’ column (in Table 2 and Table 3 of the main paper).

  • (2)

    We then apply the same embedding cluster methods to these BERT embeddings to infer the concepts/topics for each dataset.

  • (3)

    Finally, with the inferred concepts/topics from the baselines (SHAP/LIME, BERTopic and CETopic in Table 2 of the main paper) and our VALC variants (Unweighted and Weighted in Table 3 of the main paper), we perform concept editing and feed the concept-edited embeddings into the trained classifier from Step (1) to compute the editing accuracy for different methods.

Since here one does not fully finetune the BERT model (i.e., keeping the backbone fixed), the editing accuracy is expected to be lower than the ‘Finetune’ column (in Table 2 and Table 3 of the main paper), which serves as the oracle. Table 2 of the main paper shows that our VALC learns better concepts than the baselines, and Table 3 of the main paper shows that the weighted variant of VALC performs better.

Note that SHAP and LIME both interpret the CLS token’s embedding, and hence their concept vectors have the same dimension as the FLM embedding vector (768 in our case). When we conduct concept editing on the k𝑘kitalic_k’th dimension/concept, we simply subtract the CLS embedding’s dimension k𝑘kitalic_k with the average value in the batch on dimension k𝑘kitalic_k (which means that we know little about the concept/dimension k𝑘kitalic_k on this document), and keep values of the other dimensions unchanged. Note that the pruning process is exactly the same for SHAP and LIME. Therefore SHAP and LIME have identical test accuracy and accuracy gain.

Document-Level Concept Editing. We describe the document-level concept editing algorithm of VALC in Alg. 3. cmsubscript𝑐𝑚c_{m}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the ‘CLS’ embedding of document m𝑚mitalic_m (see Fig. 2 of the main paper).

Appendix E Connections Between the Defined Properties and Empirical Results

VALC is able to show which words or embeddings contributed to the document-level concept k𝑘kitalic_k. Specifically, our variational parameter (a vector) ϕm⁢j∈ℝKsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗superscriptℝ𝐾\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT describes how much word j𝑗jitalic_j contributes to document m𝑚mitalic_m. For example, the k𝑘kitalic_k-th entry of ϕm⁢jsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, denoted as ϕm⁢j⁢ksubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘\phi_{mjk}italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the paper, describes how much word j𝑗jitalic_j contributes to document m𝑚mitalic_m in terms of concept k𝑘kitalic_k. Therefore, one could use arg⁡maxj⁡ϕm⁢j⁢ksubscript𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘\arg\max_{j}\phi_{mjk}roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to find the word that contributes most to document m𝑚mitalic_m’s concept k𝑘kitalic_k. Below, we will explain these four properties using Fig. 4 as a running example.

  • (1)

    Multi-Level Structure ensures that VALC learns the dataset-, document-, and word-level concepts jointly. In Fig. 4:

    • –

      Dataset-level concepts are highlighted by the top words of each concept (the top right box of Fig. 4) and the distribution of their embeddings in the FLM (left and middle figures of Fig. 4); for example, Concept 5 (data analysis) is marked in red.

    • –

      Document-level concepts are demonstrated by each document’s topic; for instance, in the box for document (a) in Fig. 4 (right), VALC identifies Topic (Concept) 5 as key to the FLM’s prediction of the label 3 (computer science).

    • –

      Word-level concepts are identified by words in documents. For example, in the box for document (a) in Fig. 4, VALC highlights the words ‘genetic’ and ‘neural’ because they are highly related to Concept 5 (data analysis). Terms like ‘genetic algorithms’ and ‘neural networks’ are related to data analysis, aligning with the document-level concept.

  • (2)

    Normalization ensures that concept learning is regulated and smoothed, with inferred concepts appearing reasonable. Specifically, in the document-level explanation 𝜽msubscript𝜽𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and word-level explanation ϕm⁢jsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑚𝑗\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, all concepts are assigned a value within the range of 0∼1similar-to010\sim 10 ∼ 1, and all entries sum up to 1, i.e., ∑k=1Kϕm⁢i⁢j⁢k=1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑖𝑗𝑘1\sum_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{mijk}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and ∑k=1Kθm⁢k=1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜃𝑚𝑘1\sum_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{mk}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. This introduces ‘competition’ among different concepts; a larger strength for one concept means smaller strength for other concepts. Therefore, together with the help of the Dirichlet prior, it implicitly encourages sparser concept-level explanations θmsubscript𝜃𝑚\theta_{m}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which are more aligned with humans’ cognitive processes and more human-understandable (humans tend to make decisions with a small set of concepts).

  • (3)

    Additivity enables FLMs to incorporate relevant concepts and exclude irrelevant ones, thereby enhancing prediction accuracy (as shown in Table 2 and Table 3). For example, in document (a) of Fig. 4, VALC identifies Concept 5 as a highly related concept, distinguishing it from less related concepts. In practice, this may help practitioners identify key concepts in model prediction and more effectively intervene to improve model prediction accuracy (e.g., an expert may find that a concept is relevant and manually down-weight the concept to enhance the model’s prediction).

  • (4)

    Mutual Information Maximization ensures a strong correlation between (1) VALC’s generated concept explanations and (2) the explained model’s representation and predictions. In other words, it ensures that VALC is explaining the target FLM, rather than generating concept explanations irrelevant to the target FLM. For instance, in document (a) of Fig. 4, the inferred document-level Concept 5 (data analysis) effectively explains the FLM prediction, i.e., label 3 (computer science), by highlighting the intrinsic link between the data analysis concept and the class label computer science. This connection is evidenced by the words in dataset-level Concept 5 (top right box). The mutual information between the inferred Concept 5 (data analysis) and label 3 (computer science) contributes to generating high-quality explanations.

Appendix F More Conceptual Interpretation Results in Different Downstream Tasks

Dataset-Level Interpretations. As in the main paper, we leverage VALC as an interpreter on MRPC, RTE, STS-B and QQP, respectively, sample 3,3,4,433443,3,4,43 , 3 , 4 , 4 concepts (topics) for each dataset respectively, and plot the word embeddings of the top words (closest to the center 𝝁isubscript𝝁𝑖\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{i}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) in these concepts using PCA. Fig. 6(left) shows the concepts from MRPC. We can observe Concept 20 is mostly about policing, including words such as ‘suspect’, ‘police’, and ‘house’. Concept 24 is mostly about politics, including words such as ‘capital’, ‘Congress’, and ‘Senate’. Concept 27 contains mostly names such as ‘Margaret’ and ‘Mary’. Similarly, Fig. 6(right) shows the concepts from RTE. We can observe Concept 67 is related to West Asia and includes words such as ‘Quran’ and ‘Pasha’. Concept 13 is related to Europe and includes European countries/names such as ‘Prussia’ and ‘Salzburg’. Concept 91 is mostly about healthcare and includes words such as ‘physiology’ and ‘insulin’. Fig. 7 shows the concepts from STS-B. We can observe Concept 63 is mostly about household and daily life, including words such as ‘trash’, ‘flowers’, ‘airs’, and ‘garden’. Concept 60 is mostly about tools, including words such as ‘stations’, ‘rope’, ‘parachute’, and ‘hose’. Concept 84 is mostly about national security, including words such as ‘guerilla’, ‘NSA’, ‘espionage’, and ‘raided’. Concept 55 contains mostly countries and cities such as ‘Kiev’, ‘Moscow’, ‘Algeria’, and ‘Ukrainian’. Similarly, Fig. 8 shows the concepts from QQP. We can observe that Concept 12 is mostly about negative attitude, including words such as ‘boring’, ‘criticism’, and ’blame’. Concept 73 is mostly about Psychology, including words such as ‘adrenaline’, ‘haunting’, and ’paranoia’. Concept 34 is mostly about prevention and conservatives, including words such as ‘destroys’, ‘unacceptable’, and ’prohibits’. Concept 64 is mostly about strategies, including words such as ‘rumours’, ‘boycott’, and ’deportation’.

Document-Level Interpretations. For document-level conceptual interpretations, we sample two example documents from MRPC (Fig. 6(left)), three from RTE (Fig. 6(right)), six from STS-B (Fig. 7) and eight from QQP (Fig. 8), respectively, where each document contains a pair of sentences. The MRPC task is to predict whether one sentence paraphrases the other. For example, in the first document of MRPC, we can see that our VALC correctly interprets the model prediction ‘True’ with Concept 24 (politics). The RTE task is to predict whether one sentence entail the other. For example, in the second document of RTE, VALC correctly interprets the model prediction ‘True’ with Concept 13 (countries). The STS-B task is to predict the semantic similarity between two sentences with the score range of [0,5]05[0,5][ 0 , 5 ]. For example, in Document (a) of Fig. 7, we can see that VALC correctly interpret the model’s predicted similarity score ‘0.1180.1180.1180.118’ (which is relatively low,) with Concept 63 (household and daily life) and Concept 60 (tools). Similarly, in Document (f) of Fig. 7, we can see that VALC correctly interpret the model’s predicted similarity score ‘4.6724.6724.6724.672’ (which is relatively high) with Concept 84 (national security). The QQP task is to predict whether the two questions are paraphrase of each other. For example, in Document (b) of Fig. 8, we can see that VALC correctly interprets the model’s predicted label ‘False’ with Concept 73 (Psychology). Similarly, in Document (e) of Fig. 8, we can see that VALC correctly interprets the model’s predicted label ‘True’ with Concept 64 (strategies).

Word-Level Interpretations. For word-level conceptual interpretations, we can observe that VALC interpret the FLM’s prediction on MRPC’s first document (Fig. 6(left)) using words such as ‘senate’ and ‘bitty’ that are related to politics. Note that the word ‘bitty’ is commonly used (with ‘little’) by politicians to refer to the small size of tax relief/cut plans. Similarly, for RTE’s first document (Fig. 6(right)), VALC correctly identifies Concept 67 (West Asia) and interprets the model prediction ‘False’ by distinguishing between keywords such as ‘Jihad’ and ‘Al Qaeda’. likewise, we can observe that VALC interprets FLM’s prediction on Document (c) of Fig. 7 using words such as ‘cat’, ‘floor’, and ‘garlic’ that are related to household and daily life. Also, VALC interprets FLM’s prediction on Document (e) of Fig. 7 using words such as ‘soldier’ and ‘border’ that are related to national security. Similarly, for QQP’s Document (d) (Fig. 8), VALC correctly interprets the model prediction ‘True’ by identifying keywords such as ‘sabotage’ and ‘oppose’ with similar meanings in the topic of strategies. For QQP’s Document (g), (Fig. 8), VALC interprets the words in the both sentences with the same semantics, such as ‘conservative’ that is related to prevention and conservatives (note that in politics, ‘conservative’ refers to parties that tend to prevent/block new policies or legislation), and thereby predicting the correct label ‘True’.

Example Concepts.

Following Blei et al. (2003), we show the learned concepts on the RTE dataset in Table 6, which is complementary to aforementioned explanations. We select several different topics from Fig. 6. As in Sec. 5.4 of the main paper, we obtain top words from each concept via first calculating the average of the each word’s corresponding contextual embeddings over the dataset, and then getting the nearest words to each topic center (𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) in the embedding space. As we can see in Table 6, VALC can capture various concepts with profound and accurate semantics. Therefore, although FLM embeddings are contextual and continuous, our VALC can still find conceptual patterns of words on the dataset-level.

Appendix G More Quantitative Results.

Document Classification with VALC Concepts. We conducted additional experiments to perform document classification using the ‘CLS’ token’s embedding and 𝜽𝜽\thetabold_italic_θ (inferred from VALC) as features. Table 7 shows the results on three datasets. The results show that our VALC can learn meaningful concept vector 𝜽𝜽\thetabold_italic_θ, which can improve model predictions of document labels.

Appendix H Theory on the Mutual Information Maximization Property

We provide the following proof of Theorem 4.1 of the main paper.

For convenience, let Ω=(𝝁k=1K,Σk=1K)Ωsuperscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑘1𝐾\Omega=(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k=1}^{K},\Sigma_{k=1}^{K})roman_Ω = ( bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), and β=(𝜽m,𝐳m)𝛽subscript𝜽𝑚subscript𝐳𝑚\beta=(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m},{\bf z}_{m})italic_β = ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

We then introduce a helper joint distribution of the variables 𝐞msubscript𝐞𝑚{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and β𝛽\betaitalic_β, s⁢(𝐞m,β)=p⁢(𝐞m)⁢q⁢(β|𝐞m)𝑠subscript𝐞𝑚𝛽𝑝subscript𝐞𝑚𝑞conditional𝛽subscript𝐞𝑚s({\bf e}_{m},\beta)=p({\bf e}_{m})q(\beta|{\bf e}_{m})italic_s ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_β ) = italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_β | bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

According to the definition of ELBO of Section 3.4.1, in Eq. 4.1, we have

L⁢H⁢S=ℒ⁢(γm,ϕm;α,Ω)=𝔼p⁢(𝐞m)⁢[𝔼q⁢(β)⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝐞m|Ω,β)]]+𝔼q⁢(β)⁢[log⁡q⁢(β|Ω)].𝐿𝐻𝑆ℒsubscript𝛾𝑚subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝛼Ωsubscript𝔼𝑝subscript𝐞𝑚delimited-[]subscript𝔼𝑞𝛽delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚Ω𝛽subscript𝔼𝑞𝛽delimited-[]𝑞conditional𝛽Ω\displaystyle LHS={\mathcal{L}}(\gamma_{m},\phi_{m};\alpha,\Omega)={\mathbb{E}% }_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q(\beta)}[\log p({\bf e}_{m}|\Omega,\beta)]]+% {\mathbb{E}}_{q(\beta)}[\log q(\beta|\Omega)].italic_L italic_H italic_S = caligraphic_L ( italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_α , roman_Ω ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_β ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | roman_Ω , italic_β ) ] ] + blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_β ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( italic_β | roman_Ω ) ] . (20)

Since 𝔼q⁢(β)⁢[log⁡q⁢(β|Ω)]≤0subscript𝔼𝑞𝛽delimited-[]𝑞conditional𝛽Ω0{\mathbb{E}}_{q(\beta)}[\log q(\beta|\Omega)]\leq 0blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_β ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( italic_β | roman_Ω ) ] ≤ 0, we only need to prove that

𝔼p⁢(𝐞m)⁢[𝔼q⁢(β)⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝐞m|Ω,β)]]≤Is⁢(𝐞m;β)−H⁢(𝐞m)=R⁢H⁢S.subscript𝔼𝑝subscript𝐞𝑚delimited-[]subscript𝔼𝑞𝛽delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚Ω𝛽subscript𝐼𝑠subscript𝐞𝑚𝛽𝐻subscript𝐞𝑚𝑅𝐻𝑆\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q(\beta)}[\log p({\bf e% }_{m}|\Omega,\beta)]]\leq I_{s}({\bf e}_{m};\beta)-H({\bf e}_{m})=RHS.blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_β ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | roman_Ω , italic_β ) ] ] ≤ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_β ) - italic_H ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_R italic_H italic_S . (21)

Then we have that

𝔼p⁢(𝐞m)⁢[𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝐞m|β,Ω)]]subscript𝔼𝑝subscript𝐞𝑚delimited-[]subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝛽Ω\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{m}% |\beta,\Omega)]]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_β , roman_Ω ) ] ] ≤𝔼p⁢(𝐞m)⁢[𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝐞m|β)]]absentsubscript𝔼𝑝subscript𝐞𝑚delimited-[]subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝛽\displaystyle\leq{\mathbb{E}}_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}% _{m}|\beta)]]≤ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_β ) ] ]
=𝔼p⁢(𝐞m)⁢[𝔼q⁢[log⁡q⁢(𝐞m|β)p⁢(𝐞m)⁢p⁢(𝐞m)⁢p⁢(𝐞m|β)q⁢(𝐞m|β)]]absentsubscript𝔼𝑝subscript𝐞𝑚delimited-[]subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑞conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝛽𝑝subscript𝐞𝑚𝑝subscript𝐞𝑚𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝛽𝑞conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝛽\displaystyle={\mathbb{E}}_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log\tfrac{q({\bf e% }_{m}|\beta)}{p({\bf e}_{m})}\tfrac{p({\bf e}_{m})p({\bf e}_{m}|\beta)}{q({\bf e% }_{m}|\beta)}]]= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log divide start_ARG italic_q ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_β ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG divide start_ARG italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_β ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_q ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_β ) end_ARG ] ]
=𝔼p⁢(𝐞m)⁢[𝔼q⁢[log⁡q⁢(𝐞m|β)p⁢(𝐞m)]]+𝔼p⁢(𝐞m)⁢[𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝐞m)]]+𝔼p⁢(𝐞m)⁢[𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝐞m|β)q⁢(𝐞m|β)]]absentsubscript𝔼𝑝subscript𝐞𝑚delimited-[]subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑞conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝛽𝑝subscript𝐞𝑚subscript𝔼𝑝subscript𝐞𝑚delimited-[]subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝subscript𝐞𝑚subscript𝔼𝑝subscript𝐞𝑚delimited-[]subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝛽𝑞conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝛽\displaystyle={\mathbb{E}}_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log\tfrac{q({\bf e% }_{m}|\beta)}{p({\bf e}_{m})}]]+{\mathbb{E}}_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q}% [\log p({\bf e}_{m})]]+{\mathbb{E}}_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log% \tfrac{p({\bf e}_{m}|\beta)}{q({\bf e}_{m}|\beta)}]]= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log divide start_ARG italic_q ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_β ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ] ] + blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ] + blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log divide start_ARG italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_β ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_q ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_β ) end_ARG ] ]
=Is(𝐞m;β)−H(𝐞m)−𝔼q[KL(q(𝐞m|β)|p(𝐞m|β))]\displaystyle=I_{s}({\bf e}_{m};\beta)-H({\bf e}_{m})-{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[KL(q({% \bf e}_{m}|\beta)|p({\bf e}_{m}|\beta))]= italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_β ) - italic_H ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_K italic_L ( italic_q ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_β ) | italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_β ) ) ]
≤Is⁢(𝐞m;β)−H⁢(𝐞m)−0=R⁢H⁢S,absentsubscript𝐼𝑠subscript𝐞𝑚𝛽𝐻subscript𝐞𝑚0𝑅𝐻𝑆\displaystyle\leq I_{s}({\bf e}_{m};\beta)-H({\bf e}_{m})-0=RHS,≤ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_β ) - italic_H ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - 0 = italic_R italic_H italic_S , (22)

which concludes the proof of Theorem 4.1.

Appendix I Theoretical Analysis on Continuous Word Counts

Before going to the claims and proofs, first we specify some basic problem settings and assumptions. Suppose there are K+1𝐾1K+1italic_K + 1 topic groups, each of which is regarded to be sampled from a parameterized multivariate Gaussian distribution. In specific, the K+1𝐾1K+1italic_K + 1 ’th distribution of topic has a much larger covariance, and in the same time, closed to the center of embedding space. The prementioned properties can be measured by a series of inequalities:

The approximate marginal log-likelihood of word embeddings, i.e., the third term of the ELBO as mentioned in Eqn. 2 of the main paper, is:

ℒ(t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n)superscriptℒ𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{(train)}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =∑j=1Jm𝔼q⁢[log⁡p⁢(𝐞m⁢j|zm⁢j,𝝁zm⁢j,𝚺zm⁢j)]absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝚺subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗\displaystyle=\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|% z_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})]= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
=∑m,j,kϕm⁢j⁢k⁢wm⁢j⁢{−12⁢(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)T⁢𝚺k−1⁢(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)−log⁡[(2⁢π)d/2⁢|𝚺k|1/2]}.absentsubscript𝑚𝑗𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘subscript𝑤𝑚𝑗12superscriptsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘𝑇superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑘1subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘superscript2𝜋𝑑2superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑘12\displaystyle=\sum_{m,j,k}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\{-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1% }({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})-\log[(2\pi)^{d/2}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}]\}.= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_log [ ( 2 italic_π ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] } . (23)

The above equation is the training objective, yet for fair comparison of different training schemes, we calculate the approximated likelihood with word count 1111 for all words.

ℒ(e⁢v⁢a⁢l)superscriptℒ𝑒𝑣𝑎𝑙\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{(eval)}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_e italic_v italic_a italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =∑j=1Jm𝔼q⁢[log⁡p′⁢(𝐞m⁢j|zm⁢j,𝝁zm⁢j,𝚺zm⁢j)]absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐽𝑚subscript𝔼𝑞delimited-[]superscript𝑝′conditionalsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝚺subscript𝑧𝑚𝑗\displaystyle=\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log p^{\prime}({\bf e% }_{mj}|z_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma% $\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})]= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
=∑m,j,kϕm⁢j⁢k⁢{−12⁢(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)T⁢𝚺k−1⁢(𝐞m⁢j−𝝁k)−log⁡[(2⁢π)d/2⁢|𝚺k|1/2]}.absentsubscript𝑚𝑗𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚𝑗𝑘12superscriptsubscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘𝑇superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑘1subscript𝐞𝑚𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘superscript2𝜋𝑑2superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑘12\displaystyle=\sum_{m,j,k}\phi_{mjk}\{-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1% }({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})-\log[(2\pi)^{d/2}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}]\}.= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_log [ ( 2 italic_π ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] } . (24)

I.1 Gaussian Mixture Models

Suppose we have a ground truth GMM model with parameters 𝝅∗∈ℝKsuperscript𝝅superscriptℝ𝐾\mbox{\boldmath$\pi$\unboldmath}^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and {𝝁k∗,𝚺k∗}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝝁𝑘superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}^{*},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}% _{k}^{*}\}_{k=1}^{K}{ bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with K𝐾Kitalic_K different Gaussian distributions. In the dataset, let N𝑁Nitalic_N and Nssubscript𝑁𝑠N_{s}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the numbers of non-stop-words and stop-words, respectively. Then the marginal log likelihood of a learned GMM model on a given data sample 𝐞𝐞{\bf e}bold_e can be written as

p⁢(𝐞|{𝝁,𝚺},𝝅)=∑k=1K𝝅k⁢𝒩⁢(𝐞;𝝁k,𝚺k).𝑝conditional𝐞𝝁𝚺𝝅superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝝅𝑘𝒩𝐞subscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘\displaystyle p({\bf e}|\{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath},\mbox{\boldmath$% \Sigma$\unboldmath}\},\mbox{\boldmath$\pi$\unboldmath})=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mbox{% \boldmath$\pi$\unboldmath}_{k}\mathcal{N}({\bf e};\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}).italic_p ( bold_e | { bold_italic_μ , bold_Σ } , bold_italic_π ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N ( bold_e ; bold_italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (25)
